G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the cause of action arose in Suffolk County, and the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over the Defendant pursuant to G.L. c. 223A, § 3, because Defendant committed a tortious act within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B.proposition: Plaintiff was wearing a helmet, maintaining a proper speed, and adhering to all applicable traffic laws pursuant to G.L. c. 85, § 11B, which grants cyclists the same rights and responsibilities as motorists.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to operate and control his motor vehicle and to open his door in a manner that would avoid causing harm to foreseeable users of the public way, including cyclists. See G.L. c. 90, § 14, which expressly prohibits opening a vehicle door unless it is reasonably safe to do so.

Hersum v. Kenney, 341 Mass. 189 (1960).proposition: Defendant’s actions constituted a violation of G.L. c. 90, § 14, and such violation constitutes evidence of negligence as recognized in Hersum v. Kenney, 341 Mass. 189 (1960).

Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.raw_text: Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515 (1st Cir. 1990)
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence is the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise in like circumstances. See Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515 (1st Cir. 1990); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (1999).
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely sets out the elements of a negligence cause of action under Massachusetts law and cites Prosser & Keeton. While it does not use the precise phrase "failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise in like circumstances," its articulation of negligence elements (duty, breach, causation, damages) is consistent with and presupposes that standard of care. Thus, it is appropriate authority for the general Massachusetts definition of negligence used in the proposition.
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.relevant_excerpt: "In any negligence cause of action, there are four elements on which plaintiffs must adduce adequate evidence to prevail. Plaintiffs must show: (1) a legal duty owed by defendant to plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) proximate or legal cause; and (4) actual damage or injury. See W. Prosser & W. Keeton, The Law of Torts Sec. 30 (5th ed. 1985); see also Quinones, 492 F.2d at 1274."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (1999).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence is the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise in like circumstances. See Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515 (1st Cir. 1990); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (1999).
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (1999).support_reasoning: The Glidden opinion discusses the elements of negligence and emphasizes the need to prove causation, but it does not set out or quote the general Massachusetts definition of negligence as the failure to exercise the care of a reasonably prudent person in like circumstances. The court cites the Restatement and a treatise for the elements of negligence, but nowhere articulates the specific language of the claimed proposition. Thus, while consistent with that standard, the case is not direct authority for the quoted definition.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (1999).relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989).”

Commonwealth v. Campbell, 394 Mass. 77 (.proposition: Motorists have an affirmative duty to exercise due care toward cyclists lawfully using the road. See Mass. Gen. Laws c. 90, § 14; Commonwealth v. Campbell, 394 Mass. 77 (1985).
Commonwealth v. Campbell, 394 Mass. 77 (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Commonwealth v. Campbell deals with vehicular homicide while under the influence, focusing on negligence, recklessness, causation, jury instructions, and contributory negligence. It does not discuss motorists’ duties to cyclists, bicycles, or Mass. Gen. Laws c. 90, § 14, nor does it articulate any affirmative duty specific to cyclists lawfully using the road. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about a motorist’s duty toward cyclists.
Commonwealth v. Campbell, 394 Mass. 77 (.relevant_excerpt: “Contrary to the defendant’s contention, the judge did not foreclose the jury’s consideration of the victims’ conduct in determining whether the defendant acted reasonably or used due care. Rather, he instructed the jury that, if the defendant operated negligently so that the lives of the public might be endangered, they were not to consider the victims’ contributory negligence as excusing the defendant’s conduct. This instruction correctly states the law.”

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Violation of a safety statute may constitute negligence per se. See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990).
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The Bennett opinion expressly rejects negligence per se from a statutory violation. The court reiterates the Massachusetts rule that violation of a statute like G.L. c. 138, § 69 is only some evidence of negligence and does not itself establish a breach of duty. Thus Bennett is authority against, not for, the proposition that violation of a safety statute may constitute negligence per se in Massachusetts.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: "It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only 'some evidence' of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent."

Sobel v. Jones, 302 Mass. 600 (1939).proposition: A driver’s failure to maintain proper vigilance when opening a car door constitutes actionable negligence. See Sobel v. Jones, 302 Mass. 600 (1939); Kelly v. Buckley, 306 Mass. 558 (1940).
Sobel v. Jones, 302 Mass. 600 (1939).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a taxpayer suit challenging a town’s expenditure for a municipal office building and interprets a town by-law governing finance committee hearings. It does not involve automobile accidents, drivers, or the opening of car doors, and therefore provides no authority on negligence standards for drivers’ vigilance when opening car doors. The proposition is mis-cited to this case.
Sobel v. Jones, 302 Mass. 600 (1939).relevant_excerpt: This petition in equity, brought under G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 40, § 53, by certain taxpayers of the town of Westport, seeks to restrain the expenditure of money, under a vote taken on August 15, 1938, at a special town meeting, for the purpose of securing a site and constructing a municipal office building, because the matter was not properly before the town meeting by reason of the failure of the finance committee to hold a public hearing on the proposed expenditure as is required by a by-law of the town.

Kelly v. Buckley, 306 Mass. 558 (1940).proposition: A driver’s failure to maintain proper vigilance when opening a car door constitutes actionable negligence. See Sobel v. Jones, 302 Mass. 600 (1939); Kelly v. Buckley, 306 Mass. 558 (1940).

Conley v. Moran, 349 Mass. 624 (1965).proposition: A plaintiff may recover damages for both economic and noneconomic losses incurred as a result of another’s negligence. See Conley v. Moran, 349 Mass. 624 (1965).

St. Germain v. Pfeifer, 418 Mass. 511 (1.proposition: A bicyclist operating lawfully has full rights to use the roadway. See G.L. c. 85, § 11B; St. Germain v. Pfeifer, 418 Mass. 511 (1994).
St. Germain v. Pfeifer, 418 Mass. 511 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a medical malpractice decision dealing with the sufficiency of offers of proof before a malpractice tribunal and the operation of the bond requirement for indigent plaintiffs. It does not discuss bicycles, bicyclists, roadway usage, or G.L. c. 85, § 11B, nor does it address any traffic or roadway-rights issues. Thus it cannot be authority for the proposition that a lawfully operating bicyclist has full rights to use the roadway.
St. Germain v. Pfeifer, 418 Mass. 511 (1.relevant_excerpt: The case text provided contains no discussion of bicycles, bicyclists, roadway rights, or G.L. c. 85, § 11B. The entire opinion concerns medical malpractice tribunals, standards for offers of proof, doctor/nurse-patient relationships, and bond requirements under G.L. c. 231, § 60B.

Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.raw_text: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342 (1983)
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.proposition: Foreseeability of harm to a bicyclist determines the scope of duty. See Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342 (1983).
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.case_name: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not concern duty to bicyclists or use foreseeability of harm to a bicyclist to define the scope of any duty. It is a products liability/workers’ compensation/contribution case involving a truck driver and Firestone, focusing on comparative negligence, strict liability in warranty, and the effect of an employer’s negligence. While the court mentions foreseeability in passing regarding intervening conduct and product misuse, it does not frame or decide any rule about a duty owed to bicyclists or that foreseeability to a bicyclist defines the scope of duty.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.relevant_excerpt: We also note that it has long been the policy of this Commonwealth that a tortfeasor is liable “for the foreseeable intervening conduct of a third party whether that conduct is negligent or not.” Wilborg v. Denzell, 359 Mass. 279, 285 (1971), and cases cited. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 442B (1965).

Cyr v. J.I. Case Co., 363 Mass. 623 (197.raw_text: Cyr v. J.I. Case Co., 363 Mass. 623 (1973)
Cyr v. J.I. Case Co., 363 Mass. 623 (197.proposition: A defendant is liable for damages that are the natural and probable consequences of his negligent conduct. See Cyr v. J.I. Case Co., 363 Mass. 623 (1973).
Cyr v. J.I. Case Co., 363 Mass. 623 (197.support_reasoning: The opinion is entirely about sovereign/governmental immunity and the Commonwealth’s liability for creating or maintaining a private nuisance. It does not discuss general negligence principles, proximate cause, or the rule that a defendant is liable for the natural and probable consequences of negligent conduct. Thus, citing this case for that negligence proposition is inaccurate and unsupported by the text provided.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Comparative negligence does not bar recovery if Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was less than fifty percent (50%) of the total causal negligence. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; Zeller v. Cantu, 395 Mass. 76 (1985).

Zeller v. Cantu, 395 Mass. 76 (1985).proposition: Comparative negligence does not bar recovery if Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was less than fifty percent (50%) of the total causal negligence. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; Zeller v. Cantu, 395 Mass. 76 (1985).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Costs of this action, including prejudgment interest as permitted by G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
